title: How to Make Aioli

steps.headline: Place all of the ingredients except for the oil into a blender or food processor.
Blend or process briefly until smooth and creamy.
Pour the oil in gradually.
steps.description: Leave the motor running, and drizzle in the oil through a funnel. Continue until the mixture thickens. It should look pale and glossy. If it turns too thick, thin with a little bit of boiling water.

steps.headline: Transfer to a serving bowl.
steps.description: Taste to see if it is well seasoned and make adjustments if necessary.

steps.headline: Refrigerate covered until needed.
steps.description: It will keep for up to 3 days.

steps.headline: Use a whisk to mix the egg yolk, Dijon mustard, and a pinch of salt together in a bowl.
steps.description: Wait until you see the yolk and mustard start to create ribbons. Add the garlic and keep mixing.

steps.headline: Drizzle the olive oil into the mixture at a slow pace, and continue to whisk as you pour.
steps.description: Whisk for about 5 minutes to thoroughly combine everything. Slowly pour the water in to create a consistency as it thickens.

steps.headline: Dash a little salt and pepper and pour the lemon juice into the bowl.
steps.description: Set in the refrigerator until ready to use.

steps.headline: Place the garlic cloves and salt into a food processor.
Move into a ceramic or glass bowl.
Add 1/4 cup of the olive oil in a drizzle.
steps.description: Whisk as you do so, to form an emulsion.

steps.headline: Whisk in the lemon juice.
steps.description: Then add the remaining oil while still whisking to combine.

steps.headline: Transfer to a ceramic serving dish.
steps.description: If not using immediately, cover and refrigerate until needed.

text: Making Basic Aioli Place all of the ingredients except for the oil into a blender or food processor. Season with pepper to taste. Blend or process briefly until smooth and creamy.  Pour the oil in gradually. Leave the motor running, and drizzle in the oil through a funnel. Continue until the mixture thickens. It should look pale and glossy. If it turns too thick, thin with a little bit of boiling water. Transfer to a serving bowl. Taste to see if it is well seasoned and make adjustments if necessary. Refrigerate covered until needed. It will keep for up to 3 days. Making Mustard Aioli Use a whisk to mix the egg yolk, Dijon mustard, and a pinch of salt together in a bowl. Wait until you see the yolk and mustard start to create ribbons. Add the garlic and keep mixing. Drizzle the olive oil into the mixture at a slow pace, and continue to whisk as you pour. Whisk for about 5 minutes to thoroughly combine everything. Slowly pour the water in to create a consistency as it thickens. Dash a little salt and pepper and pour the lemon juice into the bowl. Set in the refrigerator until ready to use. Making Egg-Free Aioli Place the garlic cloves and salt into a food processor. Process to crush. Move into a ceramic or glass bowl.  Add 1/4 cup of the olive oil in a drizzle. Whisk as you do so, to form an emulsion. Whisk in the lemon juice. Then add the remaining oil while still whisking to combine. Transfer to a ceramic serving dish. If not using immediately, cover and refrigerate until needed. Finished.
